reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: I confess right off the bat that Amazon lives in a world of e-commerce, cloud computing and logistics algorithms—areas I’ve largely steered clear of. My philosophy is “stick with what you know,” and I know consumer products, banks, insurance and railroads far better than I know the complexities of Amazon’s operations.
2. Competitive Moat: Amazon undoubtedly enjoys scale, prime-member loyalty and a vast logistics network. Those are real advantages, but the metrics show inconsistent returns on equity (just 5.4% ROE) and an erratic earnings pattern. A moat without steady returns isn’t much of a moat in my book.
3. Management Quality: Jeff Bezos and Andy Jassy have done remarkable things, investing heavily to drive growth. But heavy reinvestment has produced negative owner earnings (–$10.4 billion) and required significant debt (1.7x equity). I like managers who think like owners, generate free cash and return it to shareholders through buybacks or dividends—neither of which you see here.
4. Financial Health & Consistency: A high debt-to-equity ratio, uneven earnings and ROIC under 3% tell me this business doesn’t consistently convert its vast revenues into durable profits. Inconsistent 27% total earnings growth over ten periods only underscores the volatility.
5. Valuation: The three-stage DCF spits out a nonsensical negative intrinsic value and a negative margin of safety. In plain terms, Amazon is trading well above any number I’m willing to pay—there’s no price cushion here.
6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: While I admire the long-run prospects of logistics and cloud, margins have already peaked around 56%, and competition from Walmart, Microsoft and others is fierce. Heavy capital intensity and low free cash flow are red flags for a business you hope to own “forever.”
7. Comparison to Portfolio: I’d rather own Coca-Cola’s predictable cash flows, Apple’s pricing power, BNSF’s durable franchise or my insurance companies—even if they offer lower headline growth—than a capital-hungry beast like Amazon at today’s prices.
In short, I’d rather spend my time flipping hamburgers at McDonald’s than own Amazon at this valuation. My answer: no.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 5.4%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.7; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 27.0% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 52.5%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
